bioghist.p: William Wagner was a gentleman scientist and avid collector of natural history specimens. After retiring from business as a merchant in 1840, he devoted himself to science. Believing that education in the sciences should be available to everyone, Wagner began offering free lectures on science at his home, Elm Grove, in 1847. Finding that interest in these lectures was strong, in 1855 Wagner founded the Wagner Free Institute of Science and moved the lectures to Spring Garden Hall. In 1859 construction began on a permanent home for his collections and his educational program, which opened to the public in 1865.

scopecontent.p: This collection comprises a series of scientific and general lectures written and delivered by William Wagner. The lectures are arranged by subject and center chiefly on conchology, geology and paleontology, and mineralogy and metallurgy; but also include lectures, for example, on education, agriculture and aesthetics. Some notable lecture titles include "Two Lectures on the Theories Respecting the Original Introduction of the Species," "Habits and Harmonies of Birds," "Remarks on the Duration of Rewards and Punishment in a Future State."

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
